p: Immature capsules of D. chryseum, collected from Godavari, Lalitpur, Central Nepal, at 1579â€‰m above sea level, were used as explants to produce protocorms in vitro. The plant was identified by the Nepalese taxonomist Dr. Keshav Rajbhandari as well as from the literature. A voucher specimen of this plant was deposited in the Tribhuvan University Central Herbarium (TUCH) (voucher number P07) in Kathmandu, Nepal. Material from the stems and leaves of the wild plants and the in vitro protocorms were subsequently analyzed for their cytotoxic activities.
